did.unittitle: Stefan Wawrowski papers
did.abstract: The collection consists of personal papers of Stefan Wawrowski, a prisoner of Dachau concentration camp, who immigrated to the United States in 1950. Mr. Wawrowski settled in Hartford, Connecticut and was active in many Polish American political and cultural organizations. The collection is enriched by many photographs from the Dachau concentration camp after libration in 1945 and from Displaced Person camp where Mr. Wawrowski stayed and worked in the camp administration until he received a refugee status and was allowed to immigrate to the United States. Also family photographs from Poland and photos from various local events are included.
did.langmaterial: Majority of the material is in Polish; some documents from the Dachau camp and from Displaced person's camp are in German, English and also Polish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of Mr. Wawrowski's personal papers, memoirs and documents related to imprisonment in the Dachau concentration camp. Also included are documents from his stay and work in administration of the Displaced Person's camp and his immigration to the US and further activities in Polish American organizations in Hartford and New Britain area in Connecticut. Collection contains of photographs from Dachau after liberation and from his family that was left in Poland - wife and son.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Mr. Stefan Wawrowski was born in Plock in Poland on June 23, 1903. He was a freedom fighter and already in 1917 he joined the Polish Military Organization. He married Leona Stanislawa Zielinska in 1926 and had one son Tadeusz born in 1935. Mr. Wawrowski worked as a telephone technician before the WW II. In 1939 he joined the Polish Underground Army; he was captured by Germans in 1940 and sent to Dachau concentration camp, prisoner number 4684, and was liberated in 1945 by the Allied forces. Mr. Wawrowski stayed at the Polish Displaced Person's camp, where he worked till he immigrated to the US in 1950 and lived in Hartford, Connecticut. Mr. Wawrowski was employed by the Royal Business Machines Company till his early retirement in 1962, due to disability. He was active in many Polish organizations the Polish World War II Veterans Post no. 10 in Hartford, member of the Polish American Congress district of Connecticut, and a president of the Polish National Fund Committee of Connecticut. For his active participation in a various organizations he received several distinguished awards: the Silver and the Gold Cross of Merit, the Knight Cross of the Most Distinguished Order of Polonia Restituta. Mr. Wawrowski never reunited with his family in Poland. He died on August 17, 1984 and is buried in Bloomfield, CT.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The original arrangement of the material was kept.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: After passing of Mr. Stefan Wawrowski the material was forwarded to the Connecticut Polish American Archives by Mr. Thaddeus Maliszewski.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Stefan Wawrowski papers 1945-1984 (CPAA 90-17). Connecticut Polish American Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.
